In this study, boron was added to MoCo bimetallic ion catalysts with carbon cloth and copper foil substrates, and it was found that adding boron could significantly reduce the hydrogen evolution overpotential of the catalysts. The morphology analysis by SEM showed that the addition of boric acid in the electrolyte could change the morphology of the catalyst, making the surface of the catalyst smooth and uniform distribution on the carrier, while the surface of the catalyst without boric acid formed agglutination. The prepared CoMoB-CC catalyst has an overpotential of 44.1 mV when the current density is -10 mA·cm−2. This paper primarily presents interesting phenomenon of the smooth effect of boric acid on the catalytic electrode, and the prepared catalyst has good catalytic performance, which provides some help for the preparation of hydrogen evolution materials. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalysis HER Overpotential Boric acid Carbon cloth Copper foil Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to environmental pollution and the lack of resources, developing new energy has become urgent. Hydrogen (H2) has gained a lot of attention because it's high heat and pollution-free. There are many ways to produce hydrogen, but the focus has always been on producing hydrogen by hydroelectrolysis [1–3]. High-performance and affordable electrocatalysts are needed to minimize the overpotential of hydrogen evolution reactions. Pt, a noble metal, possesses unoccupied D-orbitals and can adsorb various charged species mildly, making it an optimal catalyst for maintaining a hydrogen evolution overpotential near zero. However, their high cost and scarcity have prevented them from being used on a large scale in the industry [4–6]. Transition metal like Ni [7,8], Co [9,10], and Mo [11] based catalysts have been shown to accelerate water cracking and reduce the overpotential for HER. However, there is still much room for improvement in specific activities and durability. Many metal compounds, such as phosphates [12–14], sulfides [15,16], and borides [17,18], have been extensively studied.Transition metal borides (TMBs) are attractive materials, M-M, M-B, and B-B bonding characteristics are typical of transition metal borides (TMBs) and have excellent properties such as high conductivity, low impedance, and good stability. In recent years, they have been widely studied in water decomposition reactions, including Co2B and MoB2 as HER electrocatalysts [19–21]. However, according to the literature, most boron-containing catalysts have only moderate activity against HER in alkaline conditions. As an "electron deficient" element, boron has a small atomic radius and only three electrons in the outermost layer, and it is easy to get electrons to form a variety of covalent hybrid forms (sp, sp2, sp3). Transition metals have D-orbital lone electrons, or empty D-orbitals, which can supply vacant orbitals or unshared pair electrons in chemical reactions, so that boron can form a wide variety of compounds with transition metals. Transition metal catalysts' catalytic performance can be significantly boosted by surface composition adjustment and structure modulation. Boric acid is a crucial component of the smooth electrode, boric acid in electroplating not only plays a buffer role in stabilizing the ph value but also can expand the current density range to use a higher current density, and make the coating crystallized, increasing the metal ion binding force of the coating. Vanpaemel et al. prepared the Ni-based catalyst by electrodeposition. Due to the reduction of H+, the surface pH value increases, resulting in the formation and adsorption of Ni(OH)2 on Ni particles, which results in the inhibition of particle growth. However, this OH− production is canceled out by H3BO3 because it buffers the surface pH [22]. You et al. used H3BO3 to remove the residual Li on the electrode surface to increase the capacity of the electrodes. Compared with water and ethanol, the surface of the washed sample was smooth by H3BO3, which could significantly improve the charge transfer at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte. Importantly, boric acid did not cause changes in the valence state of the transition metal on the surface [21]. Therefore, CoMoB catalysts supported on carbon cloth and copper foil were prepared using continuous current electrodeposition, and how B addition affects electrochemistry performance and overpotential reduction of the catalysts was studied. In addition, the morphology of the catalyst with boric acid and the catalyst without boric acid was tested by SEM, the results showed that when boric acid was added to the substrate, the catalysts were uniformly distributed on the surface of carbon cloth or copper foil, and the catalysts showed a cauliflower shape. In the control group, no boric acid was added, and the catalysts formed agglomeration. The catalytic ability of the catalyst was improved after boric acid was added. The prepared CoMoB-CC catalyst has an overpotential of 44.1 mV when the current density is -10 mA·cm−2, and there is little overpotential loss after the stability test .The preparation process is shown in Fig. 1 . 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Boric acid (H3BO3), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), Sodium molybdate dihydrate (NaMoO4•2H2O), EDTA-2Na, Cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2•6H2O), they are all AR and purchased from Aladdin ((H2SO4 (70%), HNO3 (65%)), Carbon cloth (wos 1011, 0.35 mm), Copper foil (0.2 mm). 2.2 Experimental process First, the copper foil was immersed in 1M H2SO4, and the carbon cloth was immersed in 1M HNO3 20min for activation respectively, then cleaned with deionized water for use. Add 0.02 M Na2MoO4·2H2O, 0.12M CoCl2·6H2O, 0.2M H3BO3, 0.1M Na2SO4, 0.05M EDTA-2Na and 50ml deionized water to the three-necked flask, then mechanically stir it in a 35°C water bath for 30min while nitrogen is injected. The electrodeposition experiment used the usual three-electrode system connected to the electrochemical workstation. The working electrode comprised treated copper foil and carbon cloth, the counter electrode was a platinum sheet, and the reference electrode was a saturated calomel electrode. The deposition was carried out at -60mA·cm−2 for 10 min, during which the sample was completely immersed in the electrolyte. The prepared sample was cleaned multiple times with deionized water and dried in a 70°C oven for 20 min, and sealed to be measured. The three-way catalyst based on carbon cloth is referred to as CoMoB-CC, the catalyst based on copper foil is referred to as CoMoB-CF and other catalysts are similar. 2.3 Electrochemical characterizations At room temperature, the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst in 1 M NaOH aqueous solution was investigated. The electrochemical performance was tested using an electrochemical workstation of Vsp 300. The working electrode is prepared carbon cloth-based catalyst and copper foil-based catalyst. LSV was performed from -1.5 to -0.9 V (vs. SCE) at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was measured from -1.4 to -0.4 V (vs. SCE), and the scanning speed is 10 mV s−1. The range of EIS tests is 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz, and the scan rate is 5 mv/s. The endurance test was carried out in 1 M NaOH when the current density is -10 mA·cm−2 for a period of 12 hours on the workstation of the DH7000. 2.4 Morphological characterizations Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to examine the morphology. The microscopic structure of the surface was observed by TEM, and the crystal type was determined. A power X-ray diffraction pattern with Cu/Ka radiation operating in the 5-80° (2θ) range was used to determine the phase of catalysts. The valence states of the related elements were measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological analysis Fig. 2 depicts the surface morphology of the prepared catalyst. The results show that the catalyst grows directly on the coat of carbon cloth. For CoMoB-CC, the homogeneous growth of catalyst particles on the outer layer of carbon fiber can be noticed (Fig. 2a and b). In the high magnification diagram (Fig. 2c and d), the catalyst can be seen as a cauliflower shape, and surface folds appear, indicating a larger specific surface area. The diameter of catalyst particles is between 0.5 and 1.5um. Fig. 2e and f show that the CoMo-CC catalyst was loaded on the carbon cloth, but the distribution was uneven, and some areas formed agglomerations. Fig. 2g and h clearly shows the catalyst clusters. It demonstrates that the presence of H3BO3 in the electrolyte significantly affects the morphology and structure of the catalyst. Adding boric acid smoothes the catalyst's surface and uniformizes its distribution. The elements B, Co, and Mo of the CoMoB-CC catalyst are seen in the EDS diagram in Fig. 4. The Co and Mo elements of CoMoB-CC are distributed more uniformly than in CoMo-CC. For the CoMoB-CF catalyst, Fig. 3 a and b show that the catalyst with similar particle size is uniformly supported on the copper foil surface. Fig. 3c and d show that the catalyst comprises many spherical particles grouped to form grape clusters of varying thickness, with a diameter of around 0.5 um. In Fig. 3e and h, it can be seen that the CoMo-CF catalyst generated agglomerates on the surface of the copper foil, and the agglomeration catalyst showed irregular nanoflower under the high-power electron microscope. The surface distribution of the catalyst without boric acid in the electrolyte is not uniform when the catalyst is based on carbon cloth and copper foil. We have reason to believe that boric acid has a smooth effect on the catalyst. Combined with electrochemical performance analysis, boric acid can significantly enhance catalytic ability of the catalyst. The structure and shape of the CoMoB-CC catalyst were observed by transmission electron microscope (TEM). The low-magnification TEM graphic in Fig. 5a shows that the catalyst is mainly spherical, which is in line with the results of the SEM. The diameter of the small balls is 200∼400nm. In Fig. 5b and c, it is seen that the surface of the catalyst is mainly made up of some crystal structures embedded in the amorphous structures with uniform distribution. A relatively clear crystal phase of lattice fringes can be seen in Fig. 4 d. The distance between the lattices is mostly 0.20 nm and 0.195 nm, in accordance with the (1 2 1) and (1 5 0) crystal faces of CoMoB4, respectively. And the diffraction pattern of Fig. 4d further confirms the existence of CoMoB4. TEM results agree with XRD results, further proving the CoMoB-CC catalyst's controllable synthesis. The XRD and XPS data provided critical information for understanding their formation mechanism. Fig. 6 a is the XRD pattern of the catalysts based on carbon cloth. For CoMoB-CC, the observed peaks at 44.3° and 46.5° belong to crystal planes (1 2 1) and (1 5 0) of the Co2MoB4 (PDF#20-0333). The peak at 26.3° belongs to single crystal C (PDF#41-1487). Regarding CoMo-CC, the peak at 43.4° and 45.7° is attributed to Co2Mo3 (PDF#29-0490). For CoB-CC, It can be seen that there are peaks at 44.2°, 51.2°, and 75.85° which are attributed to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) crystal planes of metal Co (PDF#15–0806). CoMo-CC and CoB-CC also have the same single crystal C peak as CoMoB-CC. Fig. 6b shows common peaks for copper foil-based catalysts at 43.29°, 50.43°, and 74.1°, which are attributed to (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) of Cu (PDF#04-0836). XPS further obtains the valence states of elements and Fig. 6c depicts the full spectrum, and it can be seen that the catalyst is mainly made up of Co, Mo, B, O, and C. Four distinct peaks were matched for the Co 2p region of CoMoB-CC (Fig. 6d). The 782.3 and 798.1 eV peaks belong to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 of Co2+, along with two satellite peaks (787.1 and 803.6 eV) [21,22,24–26]. The significant peak can be ascribed to the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 peaks of Mo6+ species in Fig. 6e [11,26–29]. The spectral results show that B exists mainly in the metallic state (188.08) and oxidation state (192.4eV) in all boracic catalysts in the XPS diagram of Fig. 6f [23,24,30,31]. 3.2 Electrochemical activity The HER polarization curve of electrodes constructed using carbon cloth as the substrate is shown in Fig. 7 a. CoMoB-CC has an overpotential of 44.1 mV, whereas CoMo-CC has an overpotential of 74 mV. CoB-CC and Co-CC have overpotentials of 141.6 mV and 157.7 mV, respectively. It can be found that when H3BO3 is added to the electrolyte when preparing the catalyst, the overpotential of the prepared catalysts is further reduced than those without B. The interaction between B elements and transition metal ions promotes the HER process. Tafel slope is an important metric in determining reaction rates. The fitting values are shown in Fig. 7b. The Tafel slope of CoMoB-CC is approximately 95.6 mV dec−1, which is significantly lower than that of CoMo-CC(175.6 mV dec−1), CoB-CC (243 mV dec−1) and Co-CC (329.9 mV dec−1). The Tafel slope proves that bimetallic borides have outstanding hydrogen evolution activity. Fig. 7c shows the overpotential histogram of catalysts at different current densities, proving that boric acid plays a crucial role in overpotential reduction. EIS provides information on reaction rates. The charge transfer resistance Rct is represented by the arc diameter of the impedance spectrum, and the solution resistance Rs is represented by the junction of the left high-frequency area and the X-axis. In Fig. 7d, Nyquist shows that CoMoB-CC has the lowest impedance value, which also means that the rate of electron transfer is faster than that of CoMo-CC. These results are also in line with the LSV data shown in Fig. 7(a). Table 1 reports the fitting values of the impedance data of the catalyst during electrolysis.. A lower Rct value indicates that the electrocatalyst has a faster Faraday behavior and a lower contact impedance [25,27,28,32–34]. The HER polarization curve of the electrode prepared with copper foil as the base is shown in Fig. 8 a. CoMoB-CF has an overpotential of 67.6 mV, substantially lower than the CoMo-CF catalyst without boron (117.25 mV). The overpotential of CoB-CF is likewise lower than that of Co-CF, demonstrating the role of boron in decreasing catalyst overpotential. The Tafel slope of CoMoB-CF is 106.4 mV dec−1, which is significantly lower than that of CoMo-CC(184.4 mV dec−1), and the tafel slope of CoMoB-CF is also lower than that of CoMo-CF in Fig. 8b. Fig. 8c is the histogram of overpotential of copper foil-based catalysts at -10 and -20 mA·cm−2. Fig. 8d shows the impedance spectrum of the copper foil-based catalyst. As expected, the CoMoB-CF with the highest activity has the lowest Rct. However, it is worth noting that the impedance of the CoMo binary catalyst without B is the highest regardless of whether the catalyst carrier is carbon cloth or copper foil, which is consistent with the cyclic voltameter. However, its catalytic capacity is still greater than that of Co-CF and CoB-CF. The exchange current density represents the internal power in the progress of HER, and the higher the exchange current density, the smaller the external current required, and the easier the reaction is to proceed [29,30]. The exchange current density was obtained by linear fitting the catalyst polarization curve in the 0- -10 mV overpotential range. The maximum value of the CoMoB-CC catalyst is 1.12 mA·cm−2, which indicates its good catalytic activity. Table 2 shows the exchange current density of various catalysts. The Tafel slope of CoMoB-CC is 95.6 mV dec−1, ranging from 40 mV dec−1 to 120 mV dec−1. The Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism is believed to regulate the HER process of CoMoB-CC in an alkaline solution. Initially, due to the absorption of the catalyst, water molecules bind to the active site on the catalyst to generate Metal-H bonds. The intermediate hydrogen then combines to form hydrogen (the Mo hypervalent ion plays a role) [24,29,31–33,35–37]. The possible reaction pathways in 1M NaOH solution are shown in Fig. 9 . The produced CoMoB-CC exhibits substantial electrocatalytic activity and stability for the following reasons: First, charge transfer between Mo/Co metal and B atom promotes electron transfer and reduces internal resistance. Ultimately, it reduces the potential required for the reaction. Secondly, the catalyst particles covered on the surface are plump, and the small balls extrude each other to form a cauliflower shape. The surface is full of fold structures, which increases the surface area and provides abundant sites for hydrogen evolution. Third, the fiber structure of the carbon cloth provides abundant binding sites, and the catalyst is evenly distributed on the surface, further promoting the catalyst's catalytic ability. It can be seen from the impedance diagram of different overpotentials that the charge transfer resistance (RCTS) increases as the overpotential increases in Fig. 10 a–d. The electron transfer process is faster in CoMoB-CC because CoMoB-CC has a significantly lower Faraday resistance than other catalysts based on carbon cloth. In Fig. 10 e–h, this situation is also the same for copper foil-based catalysts, and it can be seen that element B is necessary in reducing the impedance of CoMo bimetallic ions and increasing the electron transfer ability [34–36,38–40]. Cyclic voltammetry helps to analyze the oxidation and reduction processes of the reaction. For several catalysts, significant oxidation peaks occur in the range of 0.2-0.4 V vs RHE, and the reduction peaks are 0 - -0.2 V vs RHE, which also means that similar reactions occur in several catalysts in 1M NaOH solution. The oxidation peak is the hydrogen desorption peak, and the reduction peak is the hydrogen adsorption peak [37,38,41,42]. The reduction peak of the CoMoB-CC catalyst in Fig. 11 a is located at the higher voltage, and the cyclic voltammetry curve of the CoMoB-CC catalyst has the highest oxidation peak and reduction peak, which also means the highest hydrogen adsorption and desorption peak, which is consistent with the catalyst having the lowest overpotential. Interestingly, the oxidation and reduction peaks of CoMo-CC catalyst are lower than that of Co-CC and CoB-CC catalysts, which corresponds to the EIS curve, and the impedance value of CoMo-CC is larger. However, its catalytic performance is better, consistent with copper foil-based catalysts in Fig. 11b. The surface hydrophilicity of the catalyst was tested. The results in Fig. 12 shows that the CoMoB-CC sample has a very low contact Angle of 33.5°, indicating that its surface is hydrophilic. In fact, the hydrophilic surface is ideal because it promotes the initial adsorption of water (reactants) on the electrode surface and promotes the separation of H2 bubbles, which is beneficial for HER catalytic kinetics. Furthermore, the stability of catalysts is also a significant assessment factor in catalytic performance. Therefore the stability of the CoMoB-CC catalyst is tested. In Fig. 13 a, there is only a tiny overpotential loss after the 12 h test, indicating that the catalyst has good stability. In Fig. 13b, the lsv test of the catalyst after 500 cv cycles shows that there is only a small loss of overpotential at the current density of -10, -20, -50 mA·cm−2, which further proves the stability of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this paper, we prepared boron-containing and boron-free catalysts on carbon cloth and copper foil, respectively. The morphology analysis proved that boric acid had a smooth effect on the catalyst surface. The surface of the catalyst doped with boron is smooth, with a small ball and accumulation, and the catalyst undoped with boron is easy to form agglomeration. Boron-doped catalyst has better electrochemical performance, the lowest overpotential of CoMoB-CC was 44.1 mV when the current density is -10 mA·cm−2, and it showed good stability in the 12h stability test. This study presents a relatively easy way to produce HER electrocatalyst in an alkaline solution, resulting in a fascinating phenomenon with vast practical prospects. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen is a vital clean energy, and reducing overpotential in hydrogen evolution has become necessary research, in which CoMo bimetal material is a promising high-efficiency hydrogen evolution material. In this study, boron was added to MoCo bimetallic ion catalysts with carbon cloth and copper foil substrates, and it was found that adding boron could significantly reduce the hydrogen evolution overpotential of the catalysts. The morphology analysis by SEM showed that the addition of boric acid in the electrolyte could change the morphology of the catalyst, making the surface of the catalyst smooth and uniform distribution on the carrier, while the surface of the catalyst without boric acid formed agglutination. The prepared CoMoB-CC catalyst has an overpotential of 44.1 mV when the current density is -10 mA·cm−2. This paper primarily presents interesting phenomenon of the smooth effect of boric acid on the catalytic electrode, and the prepared catalyst has good catalytic performance, which provides some help for the preparation of hydrogen evolution materials.
coredata.dc:title: Smoothing effect of H3BO3 on hydrogen evolution catalyst and the promotion of hydrogen evolution
